title: Audenshaw Reservoir Walk Route

images.title: S Parish / Gorton Lower Reservoir, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Gorton Lower Reservoir. The reservoirs were completed between 1825 and 1826. Able to supply almost 1 million imperial gallons of water per day to the city of Manchester and the surrounding area; they were used until 1963.

images.title: Keith Williamson / Gorton Upper Reservoir, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Gorton Upper Reservoir. One of the reservoirs at Gorton built by Manchester Corporation to store water for the city. Looking north from SJ90219646

images.title: Gerald England / Gorton Upper  Reservoir, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The bridge between the Southern and Northern arms of Gorton Upper Reservoir.

images.title: Gerald England / Gorton Upper  Reservoir, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The bank of Gorton Upper Reservoir looking down its Southern Arm.

images.title: Gerald England / Canoes on Gorton Lower Reservoir, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Canoes on Gorton Lower Reservoir

images.title: Gerald England / Bench at Gorton Lower Reservoir, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bench at Gorton Lower Reservoir. One of three overlooking the reservoir which is used for sailing and canoeing.

description: This walk uses waymarked walking trails to visit the Ashton Canal and the Gorton Reservoirs in Audenshaw, Manchester. It's a nice waterside walk, taking place on largely flat trails. The walk starts from the Guide Bridge train station which is right next to the canal in Audenshaw. You can pick up the towpath and follow it west toward Fairfield. Here you pick up the Tameside Trail and follow it south towards the reservoirs. You'll pass along the Upper and Lower Gorton Reservoirs before coming to Debdale Park where the route finishes. To extend the walk continue south on the Tameside Trail and you will soon come to Reddish Vale Country Park. The park contains a Visitor Centre, woodland trails, Community Orchard and Garden, Butterfly Conservation Field and a Dipping Pond. Highfield Country Park is also located in this area in Levenshulme.
